citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have an effective program in place to control mammalian pests. Two mice were observed in the
enclosure housing three saki monkeys. These monkeys share an enclosure with two sloths. Pests such as rodents can
affect the health and wellbeing of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food, surfaces, and animal housing
areas. Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to control insects, external
parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the
animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.

The facility does not have an effective program in place to control mammalian pests. Two mice were observed in the
enclosure housing two sloths. These sloths share an enclosure with three saki monkeys. Pests such as rodents can affect
the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food, surfaces, and animal housing areas.
Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, and
avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in
animal areas.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have an effective pest program to control mammalian pests. Active mouse activity was observed in
two avian areas. In the corridor near the interior ostrich enclosures, the inspector observed a mouse running along the
wall behind a rodent trap. A lidded plastic container stored nearby was partly filled with pelleted ostrich food and had a
hole chewed in the lid, allowing rodents access to the food. There was a moderate amount of rodent feces accumulated
around other items used by the facility (e.g. maintenance items) that were also stored nearby.
Two mice were observed eating scattered birdseed near the tortoise hut in the Tropical Encounters enclosure. This area
is one of the feeding areas for birds housed in the enclosure. While the food is presented to the birds on a platform that
rodents can’t access, finches often scatter the seed when eating. The inspector observed finches foraging in the ground
for scattered food in other areas of the enclosure.
Pests such as rodents can affect the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food,
surfaces, and animal housing areas. Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program
to control insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and
reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by April 18, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility does not have an effective program in place to control mammalian pests. Two mice were observed in the 
enclosure housing three saki monkeys. These monkeys share an enclosure with two sloths. Pests such as rodents can 
affect the health and wellbeing of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food, surfaces, and animal housing 
areas. Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to control insects, external 
parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the 
animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not have an effective program in place to control mammalian pests. Two mice were observed in the 
enclosure housing two sloths. These sloths share an enclosure with three saki monkeys. Pests such as rodents can affect 
the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. 
Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to control insects, ectoparasites, and 
avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in 
animal areas. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility does not have an effective pest program to control mammalian pests. Active mouse activity was observed in 
two avian areas. In the corridor near the interior ostrich enclosures, the inspector observed a mouse running along the 
wall behind a rodent trap. A lidded plastic container stored nearby was partly filled with pelleted ostrich food and had a 
hole chewed in the lid, allowing rodents access to the food. There was a moderate amount of rodent feces accumulated 
around other items used by the facility (e.g. maintenance items) that were also stored nearby. 
 
Two mice were observed eating scattered birdseed near the tortoise hut in the Tropical Encounters enclosure. This area 
is one of the feeding areas for birds housed in the enclosure. While the food is presented to the birds on a platform that 
rodents can’t access, finches often scatter the seed when eating. The inspector observed finches foraging in the ground 
for scattered food in other areas of the enclosure.

Pests such as rodents can affect the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating food, 
surfaces, and animal housing areas. Correct by February 25, 2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program 
to control insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and 
reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by April 18, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
